prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers of James Boyd,1938-1941, in the Clifton Waller Barrett Library, Accession #7684 , Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: American writer, 1888-1944, known for historical novels, particularly Drums, Bitter Creek, and Roll River.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains a manuscript of bibliographical notes by Frank Stone on Boyd, correspondence of Stone and Boyd, and photographs of Boyd.

did.unittitle: Manuscripts 1938
Bibliographical notes by Frank Stone regarding James Boyd's works. ca. 1938

Correspondence
1938-1939
Jacob Blanck to R.R. Bowker Co. to Frank Stone 1938 July 11

scopecontent.p: Blanck discusses corrections for Drums,making Blanck's copy correspond with Stone's.

did.unittitle: Collector's Book Shop to Frank Stone 1938 October 1

scopecontent.p: Collector's Book Shop can offer a first edition of Long Hunt,as new, in dust jacket for $2.50.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Joseph H. Poli of Charles Scribner's 1938 November 9

scopecontent.p: Stone requests correct bibliographical information on specific lines of Drums,Marching On,Long Hunt,and Roll River.He also requests the number of copies in the first edition of each title, and any other data in regards to issues, etc.

did.unittitle: Joseph Poli to Frank Stone 1938 November 10

scopecontent.p: Poli sends the biliographic information Stone requested and notes that Bitter Creekwill probably be published in January or February.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1938 November 30

scopecontent.p: Stone is preparing a checklist of first editions of Boyd's books for publication in Publisher's Weekly.He asks Boyd to read the list for errors and would also appreciate knowing of any short pieces that appeared in book form. He notes that there is a demand for first editions and a need for authoritative information on identifying them.

did.unittitle: James Boyd to Frank Stone 1938 December 15

scopecontent.p: No checklist enclosed in letter. Scribner's would know better than he how to identify a first edition.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1938 November 30

scopecontent.p: Enclosing the checklist. Needs help on Marching Onas he has seen copies in three different states. Includes a description of Bitter Creekand asks about the existence of shorter pieces such as short stories, prefaces, etc.

did.unittitle: James Boyd to Frank Stone 1938 December 28

scopecontent.p: Hunting Sketchesby Anthony Trollope, Gosden Head, 1928, has an introduction by him. As We Are,a collection of short stories edited by Walter B. Pitkin, contains his Shif'less.Miss [June] Cleveland who has an autographed copy of Marching Onis not a friend.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1938 December 30

scopecontent.p: Stone thanks Boyd for information on Hunting Sketchesand As We Are.Has written Library of Congress for publication dates as well as information on first issue of Marching On. Would Boyd inscribe his first editions? Mr. Poli has promised him a set of galley proofs, a sought after collector's item.

did.unittitle: R. E. Roberts, Collector's Book Shop, to Frank Stone 1938 November 30

scopecontent.p: The Trollope was published at $10.00 in 1933. Can get a new copy at that price. Three later English editions all have the Boyd introduction. Pitkin,published in 1923, is out of print. Does he wish them to advertise for it?

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Valta Parma 1939 January 3.

scopecontent.p: Stone writes the Library of Congress Rare Book Curator asking help with the checklist. Needs transcripts of title page and copyright page of Marching On,Hunting Sketchesby Anthony Trollope, and As We Are,edited by Walter B. Pitkin.

did.unittitle: Valta Parma to Frank Stone 1939 January 14

scopecontent.p: Encloses a memo prepared by an assistant regarding the requested title pages.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Valta Parma 1939 January 17

scopecontent.p: Stone thanks Parma for her letter and memo. Requests transcript of copyright page of Marching On.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Jacob Blanck 1939 February 21
did.physdesc: TL (carbon) 1 p. Enclosing TM (carbon( list of Boyd's books

scopecontent.p: Encloses Boyd list. Interested to hear what Blanck has learned about Marching On.Stone is also enclosing a list of typographical errors for future use. Has seen copy in wrapper with no mention of publication date as well as the copy inscribed for June Cleveland, a store buyer. Reminds him not to forget the M.F.H. after Boyd's name in Hunting Sketches.

did.unittitle: Jacob Blanck to Frank Stone 1939 February 24

scopecontent.p: List arrived. Asks questions regarding Drumsand Marching On. Does Stone want to tackle them?

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to H.R. Huntting Company 1939 March 16

scopecontent.p: Stone is preparing a checklist of first editions of Boyd's books. Learned from Scribner's that in 1925 Huntting had 250 copies of Drumsbound in buckram. Wants to locate and buy one. If that not possible, do they have a copy he could use for comparison purposes? Mentions points he wants to compare in establishing the true first edition.

did.unittitle: J.A. Bousquet of H.R. Huntting to Frank Stone 1939 March 20

scopecontent.p: Copies of Drumsare exhausted and have no records of where copies were sold. Suggests he advertise in Publisher s Weekly.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to J. A. Bousquet 1939 March 21

scopecontent.p: Thanks Bousquet for reply. Says his first letter wasn't clear. Does Huntting have a copy of Drumsin their library and would they be willing to compare points? A rare book dealer is advertising for a first edition. Scribner's sent them 250 copies of the first edition. Needs to know if they were distributed before the publication date of March 27, 1925.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1939 March 21

scopecontent.p: A question has arisen on Drums.Does he have a copy of the first edition and would he be willing to compare some points which he lists? Mr. Poli of Scribner's has sent copy of the galleys of Bitter Creekand Stone is getting a cop of the first edition. Offers his congratulations on the fine reviews it is receiving. In an ANS note at the bottom of the page Boyd answers Stone's questions from his own copy but does not know if it is a genuine first edition.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Valta Parma 1939 March 21

scopecontent.p: Stone is troubling Parma once more to ask for a transcript of the title page of her copy of Drums.

did.unittitle: Valta Parma to Frank Stone 1939 March 22

scopecontent.p: Two Library of Congress copies of Drumsnot on shelves. Gives copyright information for third copy. Also includes information for Marching Onwhich is in original binding but greatly worn. Does Stone think it worthy of preservation in the Rare Book Room? Has also found copyright deposit of Long Huntin original binding. Is that worth transferring?

did.unittitle: J.A. Bousquet to Frank Stone 1939 March 23

scopecontent.p: Scribner's furnished them 250 copies of Drumsin 1925 but they kept no sales records. By an understanding with publisher the books were not to be sold before the publication date.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to J.A. Bousquet 1939 March 25

scopecontent.p: Stone thanks Bousquet for his assistance.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Valta Parma 1939 March 25

scopecontent.p: Thanks her for her information which corresponds with copies he has seen. Copies are scarce and an advertisement in Publisher's Weeklybrought no response. Scribner's published 2500 copies of Drumsbut because of its popularity the first edition is rare. First printing of Marching Onwas supposedly 28,000 copies. In addition to 26,000 copies of Long Huntthere was a limited edition of 260 copies published simultaneously.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to Jacob Blanck 1939 March 25

scopecontent.p: Stone sends the revised James Boyd checklist. Blanck should feel free to edit his notes under Drumsand Marching On.Reminds him to add M.F.H. under Hunting Sketchesand requests ten personal copies.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1939 March 25

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for comparing his copy of Drumswhich he thinks is the second printing and explains why. Encloses copy of the list he mailed to Publisher's Weeklyand will send him a published copy.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1939 April 20

scopecontent.p: Encloses copy of Publisher's Weeklywith the checklist of Boyd first editions. Would Boyd be willing to inscribe Stone's personal copies?

did.unittitle: James Boyd to Frank Stone 1939 April 23

scopecontent.p: Thanks Stone for the list and will be glad to autograph his books.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1939 April 29

scopecontent.p: Is sending the books for autographing except for the elusive first edition of Drums.Thanks him for his trouble.

did.unittitle: Jacob Blanck to Frank Stone 1939 May 10

scopecontent.p: Encloses a token of appreciation and esteem though Publisher's Weeklydoes not pay for checklists. Hopes this will enable him to buy more books and produce more checklists.

did.unittitle: Frank Stone to James Boyd 1939 May 11

scopecontent.p: The box of autogrpahed books arrived. Hopes Boyd will come to New York so he can thank him personally.

did.unittitle: Secretary of Frank Stone to Jacob Blanck 1939 May 13

scopecontent.p: Wishes to acknowledge Blanck's letter and check in Stone's absence.

did.unittitle: Photographs 1939, 1941, n.d.
Photograph 1939.

scopecontent.p: Head and shoulders photograph by Pinchot.

did.unittitle: Photograph 1939 March 12.

scopecontent.p: Head and shoulders.

did.unittitle: Photograph n.d.

scopecontent.p: Group photograph of James Boyd, Stephen Vincent Benét, Marc Connelly and Dorothy Thompson.

did.unittitle: Photograph 1941 March 18
did.physdesc: Photograph of rehearsal of One more free man, 8 x 10 inches.

scopecontent.p: Photograph of rehearsal of the radio play includes Margo, Sydney Lumet, Betty Field and Myron McCormick.
